awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Large: Collaborative: Towards a Science of Censorship Resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
The proliferation and increasing sophistication of censorship warrants continuing efforts to develop tools to evade it. Yet, designing effective mechanisms for censorship resistance ultimately depends on accurate models of the capabilities of censors, as well as how those capabilities will likely evolve. In contrast to more established disciplines within security, censorship resistance is relatively nascent, not yet having solid foundations for understanding censor capabilities or evaluating the effectiveness of evasion technologies. Consequently, the censorship resistance tools that researchers develop may ultimately fail to serve the needs of citizens who need them to communicate. Designers of these tools need a principled foundation for reasoning about design choices and tradeoffs. 

To provide such a foundation, this project develops a science of censorship resistance: principled approaches to understanding the nature of censorship and the best ways to facilitate desired outcomes. The approach draws upon empirical studies of censorship as the foundation for models and abstractions to allow us to reason about the censorship-resistant technologies from first principles. The project aims to characterize and model censorship activities ranging from blocked search results to interference with international network traffic. The research develops theoretical models of censorship; reconciles these with large-scale empirical measurements; and uses these observations to design censorship-resistance tools to deploy in practice, as both components of Tor and standalone systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development, deployment, and evaluation of a wide variety of censorship circumvention and privacy enhancing technologies, ranging from new technologies to evade censorship, to widely used and deployed technologies such as virtual private networks (VPNs), to emerging Internet protocols and standards such as Oblivious DNS (ODNS) and encrypted domain name system (DNS) (including DNS-over-HTTPS, or DoH).

One of the flagship outcomes from this research project was the design, implementation, standardization, and deployment of Oblivious DNS, which decouples a DNS queries from the IP address issuing the query. The project developed the design and first implementation of this protocol, introduced it at the Internet engineering task force (IETF) DNS privacy working group, helped develop the standard, and ultimately transferred the technology to deployment at Cloudflare and Apple.

Another significant aspect of this project was to understand how users conceived and used technologies to assist in censorship circumvention. In particular, the project involved several multi-year, large-scale user studies, to understand user attitudes and awareness concerning virtual private networks (VPNs) and encrypted DNS (particularly DoH), which has become increasingly relevant over the course of the research project due to the fact that browser vendors have deployed encrypted DNS (and routed DNS queries to third party providers) by default, typically without users' knowledge.  Work in this area continues, and has catalyzed an entirely new research theme, exploring the ways that DNS can be augmented or modified in deployment to better preserve user privacy. Research continues to explore a variety of threat models in this regard, and thus the research project has laid important groundwork for understanding the privacy and censorship risks that users face as a result of their dependence on the DNS.

The work has also explored other surveillance risks, including risks associated with automated voice assistants.


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: Nicholas G Feamster
